Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of Caudal Adjuvants in Pediatric Surgery

Background: This randomised controlled trial aimed to compare the duration of postoperative analgesia provided by morphine, clonidine, and dexmedetomidine as adjuvants to 0.2% ropivacaine in caudal blocks for children undergoing infraumbilical surgeries.

Methods: Conducted at a tertiary hospital in southern India, 63 children aged 1–6 years with ASA physical status I or II were randomised to receive a caudal block with either dexmedetomidine 1 μg/kg (Group D), morphine 30 μg/kg (Group M), or clonidine 1.5 μg/kg (Group C), along with 0.2% ropivacaine. Randomisation was computer-generated with allocation concealment using sealed envelopes. Blinding included patients, clinicians, and outcome assessors. The primary outcome was the duration of analgesia, measured until the first rescue analgesic was required.

Results: The median duration of analgesia was 380 minutes for Group D, 360 minutes for Group C, and 405 minutes for Group M, with no statistically significant difference (P = 0.843). Adverse events included intraoperative hypotension in 43.5% of Group D, 27.8% of Group C, and 22.7% of Group M (P = 0.299). No significant differences in postoperative nausea, vomiting, or sedation were observed.

Interpretation: Morphine, dexmedetomidine, and clonidine provide similar analgesic duration and side-effect profiles in pediatric infraumbilical surgeries. Trial registration: CTRI/2020/07/026481. Funding: None.
